channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nobel Writer Sees Politics Through Lens of Mistrust
item.description: Svetlana Alexievich, the recipient of the Nobel Prize for Literature, gave a bleak assessment of the political situation in Russia and her native Belarus to journalists on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: CHARLY WILDER

item.title: Suicide Bombers Kill at Least 38 at Market and Refugee Camp in Chad
item.description: Chadian officials suspect that the attacks, which also wounded more than 50 people, were carried out by members of the Boko Haram extremist group from neighboring Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Refugees, Stuck in Grinding U.S. Process, Wait and Hope
item.description: While the Obama administration has promised to increase the number of refugees the United States accepts, the process for vetting and admitting them takes up to two years.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Refugees arriving in Greece last month. The Obama administration has promised to increase the number it takes, but the process takes up to two years for each.

item.title: A Steinway From New York Meets Virtuosos in Havana
item.description: On Friday, about 3,000 Cubans and foreigners sat in plastic chairs in a plaza in Havana, their eyes darting between international virtuosos almost within arm’s reach.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BERKELEY COHEN

item.title: Spying Case Against U.S. Envoy Is Falling Apart, and Following a Pattern
item.description: The home and office of Robin L. Raphel, a former adviser to the State Department, were raided last year in search of proof that she was spying for Pakistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO, MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Robin L. Raphel, right, a State Department adviser, meeting with Sartaj Aziz, Pakistan’s national security adviser, in Islamabad in 2013. Ms. Raphel has been the target of a spying investigation.

item.title: At Military Parade, a Rare Public Speech by North Korea’s Leader
item.description: Kim Jong-un gave his first public speech in three years to stress his readiness to “fight any form of war” with the United States.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The 70th anniversary of the ruling Workers’ Party was celebrated in Pyongyang on Saturday with what appeared to be one of the largest military parades North Korea had ever organized.

item.title: Nobel Renews Debate on Chinese Medicine
item.description: When Tu Youyou, a retired researcher of a Chinese medicine academy, won China’s first Nobel in science, it raised old questions on tradition.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A patient with insomnia at the acupuncture hospital of the China Academy of Chinese Medical Sciences on Friday.

item.title: Geoffrey Howe, Cabinet Minister Who Hastened Thatcher’s Fall, Dies at 88
item.description: A Conservative British cabinet member who advanced Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher’s economic policies, Mr. Howe resigned and hastened her downfall in 1990.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN
item.media:description: Geoffrey Howe with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in 1980. An ally of Mrs. Thatcher’s, he ultimately split with her.

item.title: Opinion: The Refugees at Our Door
item.description: We are paying Mexico to keep people from reaching our border, people who are fleeing Central American violence.
item.dc:creator: SONIA NAZARIO
item.media:credit: Katie Orlinsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hermanos en el Camino, an immigrant shelter in southern Mexico.

item.title: Afghan Family Remembers a Loving Son Killed in Airstrike on Kunduz Hospital
item.description: Najibullah Momand, who worked as a janitor at the Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, was one of at least a dozen staff members who died in the recent attacks on the hospital.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Najibullah Momand, who worked as a janitor, died during attacks on a Doctors Without Borders hospital.

item.title: 4 U.S. Military Efforts on ISIS and Syria Yield Mixed Results
item.description: The Obama administration’s announcement on Friday that it had halted a program to train and equip Syrian fighters reflected the complications in the region.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Alexander Kots/Komsomolskaya Pravda, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers fired artillery near Morek, a village in Hama Province. Russia’s intervention has given a boost to the government, and complicated American efforts.

item.title: Explosions During Peace Rally in Ankara, Turkey’s Capital, Kill Scores
item.description: Turkish authorities were investigating claims that the attacks, which also wounded 246, were the work of suicide bombers.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: A man held the hand of his friend who was among more than 90 killed in Ankara on Saturday, in an attack weeks before elections.

item.title: Joker Arroyo, Who Challenged Martial Law in the Philippines, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Arroyo, a politician and lawyer who was a trusted adviser to Corazon C. Aquino, counseled, bedeviled and helped topple Philippine presidents.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: Joker Arroyo, seated, with fellow senators acting as judges in the impeachment trial of the chief justice of the Supreme Court, Renato Corona, in Manila in 2012.

item.title: The Refugee Crisis in Europe: How Is Asylum Granted?
item.description: New York Times correspondents and editors answer readers questions about the European migrant crisis. Submit your questions.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A Hungarian Red Cross worker gave water to a migrant who arrived at the railway station in Zakany from Croatia last month.

item.title: Message From China’s Leader, Xi Jinping, to North Korea May Signal Thaw
item.description: Mr. Xi dispatched one of his most senior officials to celebrate the 70th anniversary Saturday of the founding of North Korea’s ruling party.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: South Korean television showed Kim Jong-un, North Korea's leader, watching a military parade in the North's capital, Pyongyang, on Saturday with Liu Yunshan. Mr. Liu, second from right, is the highest-ranking Chinese official to visit the North since Mr. Kim took power.

item.title: For Families of Germanwings Victims, Anger Burns Through Grief
item.description: Families in a quiet German town are still struggling with the holes in their lives since a pilot killed himself along with their loved ones.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jürgen Strang's son, Steffen, died in the Germanwings plane crash in March. He and some other relatives of the victims are weighing whether to file a lawsuit against Lufthansa in the United States.

item.title: Obama Administration Ends Effort to Train Syrians to Combat ISIS
item.description: The effort to build a rebel force against the Islamic State failed in part because many rebels focused on a campaign against President Bashar al-Assad, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: News Agency Compiles New Tally for Stampede’s Death Toll
item.description: The crush outside Saudi Arabia’s holy city of Mecca killed at least 1,470 people during the hajj last month, The Associated Press said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Guatemala: More Bodies Are Recovered in Neighborhood Hit by Landslide
item.description: A week after a hillside collapsed, officials said that 253 bodies had been recovered and that 374 people were still missing.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: After Recovering From Ebola, Nurse Is Hospitalized Again in London
item.description: The nurse was in the isolation unit of the Royal Free Hospital with what was described as an unusual late complication.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
